title: The race to sequence the human genome - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What is the length of the genetic instructions inside every cell in the human body?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To sequence the entire human genome over 20 years with $5 billion of public funds

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The Human Genome Project divided the genome into smaller chunks, while Celera used a different sequencing technology

options.label: C
options.text: The Human Genome Project worked collaboratively, while Celera worked alone

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It allowed scientists to publish their findings quickly and get recognition for their work

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the research community

options.label: B
options.text: Celera completed the sequence first, and the Human Genome Project was left behind

options.text: Neither group was able to complete the sequence

options.label: D

title: How can countries measure the well-being of their citizens?

multiple-choice.question: What is a significant limitation of using GDP as a measure of national growth?

options.label: C
options.text: It is only used by developed countries.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: SEDA provides a comprehensive view of a country's well-being, including social and environmental factors, while GDP only measures economic growth.

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Implementing policies that restrict women's participation in politics

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Improving well-being requires good leadership, clear goals, and policies specifically focused on making the country and the world a better place for its people.

options.label: C
options.text: Improving well-being requires a focus on economic growth at the expense of social and environmental sustainability.

options.label: D

options.text: The length is three times the width.

options.label: C
options.text: The length is approximately six times the width.

options.label: D
options.text: The length is eight times the width.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Slow-moving water remains the same as fast-moving water.

options.label: D
options.text: Slow-moving water is faster than fast-moving water.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the fast-moving water near the outside bank of the stream?

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same speed and depth.

options.label: C
options.text: It sweeps out of the curve and carries momentum across the channel, slamming into the other side.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: Makes it difficult to pay attention to the present, affecting short-term memory storage

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of challenging the brain with activities like learning a new language?

options.label: B
options.text: Has no effect on brain health

title: Growth Mindset vs Fixed Mindset: An Introduction

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between individuals with a growth mindset and those with a fixed mindset?

options.label: A
options.text: People with a growth mindset believe that intelligence is determined by genetics, while those with a fixed mindset believe that intelligence is developed through experience.

options.label: B
options.text: People with a growth mindset believe that intelligence can be developed, while those with a fixed mindset believe that intelligence is a fixed trait.

options.label: C
options.text: People with a growth mindset are more focused on achieving success, while those with a fixed mindset are more focused on learning from failures.

options.label: D
options.text: People with a growth mindset think that intelligence is something you either have or you don't, while those with a fixed mindset think that intelligence can be changed.

multiple-choice.question: Which analogy best describes the concept of intelligence according to individuals with a growth mindset?

options.label: A
options.text: Intelligence is like a fixed puzzle that can be solved in one way.

options.label: B
options.text: Intelligence is like a muscle that can be developed through effort and challenge.

options.label: C
options.text: Intelligence is like a light bulb that can be turned on or off.

options.label: D
options.text: Intelligence is like a book that contains all the knowledge one needs.

multiple-choice.question: How do students with a growth mindset typically approach learning in school?

options.label: A
options.text: They avoid asking questions and focus on showing off their intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: They ask questions and view effort as a way to learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: They give up in the face of a challenge and focus on preserving their image.

options.label: D
options.text: They focus on hiding their lack of understanding and avoid seeking help.

multiple-choice.question: How do students with a growth mindset typically respond to challenges or setbacks?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more likely to give up in the face of a challenge and view it as a threat to their ego.

options.label: B
options.text: They view challenges as opportunities to learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: They are more likely to avoid asking questions when they don't understand something and focus on showing off their intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more likely to focus on preserving their image of being smart and avoid taking risks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of students with a growth mindset in school?

options.label: A
options.text: To learn new things and develop their intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: To show off their intelligence and hide their lack of understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid asking questions and preserve their image of being smart.

options.label: D
options.text: To achieve good grades and avoid challenges.

multiple-choice.question: How do individuals with a growth mindset view effort in relation to intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Effort is seen as a negative factor that indicates a lack of intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Effort is seen as a positive factor that helps develop intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Effort is seen as a neutral factor that has no impact on intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Effort is seen as a fixed trait that cannot be changed.

multiple-choice.question: This question has been removed as it is a duplicate of question 4.
This question has been removed as it is a duplicate of question 4.
What is the relationship between students' disagreement with statements about fixed intelligence and their mindset?

options.label: A
options.text: The more students disagree with statements about fixed intelligence, the more they have a fixed mindset.

options.label: B
options.text: The more students disagree with statements about fixed intelligence, the more they have a growth mindset.

options.label: C
options.text: The more students agree with statements about fixed intelligence, the more they have a growth mindset.

options.label: D
options.text: The more students agree with statements about fixed intelligence, the more they have a fixed mindset.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between the goals of students with a fixed mindset and those with a growth mindset?

options.label: A
options.text: Students with a fixed mindset want to learn new things, while students with a growth mindset want to show off their intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Students with a fixed mindset want to show off their intelligence, while students with a growth mindset want to learn new things.

options.label: C
options.text: Students with a fixed mindset want to hide their lack of understanding, while students with a growth mindset want to preserve their image of being smart.

options.label: D
options.text: Students with a fixed mindset want to achieve good grades, while students with a growth mindset want to develop their intelligence.

title: The treadmill's dark and twisted past - Conor Heffernan

title: What happens when your DNA is damaged? - Monica Menesini

multiple-choice.question: How many times per day does the DNA in a single cell get damaged?

What is a potential consequence of non-homologous end joining when it doesn't have a template to work with?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the accuracy of DNA repair

options.label: B
options.text: It can cause genes to get mixed up or moved around

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on DNA repair

options.label: D
options.text: It always results in cell death

options.label: A
options.text: To introduce random changes to the DNA

options.label: B
options.text: To ignore errors in the DNA

options.label: D
options.text: To maintain the integrity of the DNA

multiple-choice.question: What are defects in DNA repair associated with?

options.label: D
options.text: Premature aging and many kinds of cancer

title: How misused modifiers can hurt your writing

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the grammatical mistake that occurs when a modifier is not clearly linked to the word it is intended to modify, as seen in the example "Thief robs town with world's largest chocolate bunny"?
What is the primary function of modifiers in a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: To change the meaning of a sentence

options.label: D
options.text: To provide additional information about other parts of a sentence

multiple-choice.question: What type of modifier is "Having robbed the bank in record time" in the sentence "Having robbed the bank in record time, it was possible to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit as well"?
What term describes a modifier that appears to be unrelated to any other part of a sentence?
What term describes a modifier that is positioned between two parts of a sentence and could potentially refer to either one?
How can the meaning of a squinting modifier be clarified in a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: By placing the modifier closer to the word it modifies

options.label: C
options.text: By adding more information to the sentence

options.label: D
options.text: By rephrasing the sentence entirely or placing the modifier closer to the word it modifies

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of avoiding verbal ambiguity in sentence construction?

options.label: B
options.text: To add unnecessary information to sentences

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain clarity and grammatical accuracy

options.label: D
options.text: To change the meaning of sentences

multiple-choice.question: Which type(s) of grammatical mistakes can create unintentional ambiguity in a sentence?
How can a misplaced modifier be corrected in a sentence?

options.label: B
options.text: By placing the modifier closer to the word it modifies

options.label: C
options.text: By rephrasing the sentence to make it clearer what the modifying phrase refers to

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a misplaced modifier in a sentence, as seen in the example "Thief robs town with world's largest chocolate bunny"?

options.label: A
options.text: The sentence implies the thief was armed with a giant chocolate animal

options.label: C
options.text: The sentence implies the town was robbed by a thief

options.label: D
options.text: The sentence is unclear because the modifying words modify the wrong thing
